homeRYSh: Join us in celebrating the grand chariot festival of Lord Jagannath
homeRYD:
Jagannath Ratha Yatra is one of the most revered and vibrant festivals in India. Celebrated with immense devotion, it marks the annual journey of Lord Jagannath along with His siblings Balabhadra and Subhadra from the main temple to the Gundicha temple. The highlight of the festival is the pulling of beautifully decorated wooden chariots by thousands of devotees with ropes and chants of 'Jai Jagannath!' echoing through the streets. 

This sacred procession symbolizes unity, devotion, and the Lord’s love for all beings, transcending all boundaries. It is a spiritual and cultural celebration that brings people together in divine joy. Whether you're a pilgrim or a first-time visitor, witnessing Ratha Yatra is an unforgettable experience that touches the heart and uplifts the soul.
homeEventsSh: Be a part of our upcoming spiritual and cultural gatherings
homeAboutSh: A Sacred Place of Peace and Devotion
homeAbout:
Shri Jagannath Dham is a sacred spiritual center located in Sector 7, Udaipur, Rajasthan. Rooted in the timeless traditions of Sanatan Dharma, the temple is dedicated to Lord Jagannath, along with Balabhadra, Subhadra, and Sudarshan. More than a place of worship, it is a vibrant hub for cultural celebrations, daily aartis, community gatherings, and spiritual learning. 

Here, devotion meets service — with opportunities for satsang, seva, and rituals that enrich the soul. Whether you seek peace, blessings, or a deeper connection to your roots, Shri Jagannath Dham welcomes everyone with open arms. The temple also preserves ancient Vedic practices, traditional art, and architecture, creating an atmosphere of divine presence. Come, be a part of this ever-growing spiritual family and experience the grace, warmth, and vibrant spirit of Lord Jagannath.

rYDHeading: The Sacred Story Behind the Ratha Yatra
rathaYatraProcess: According to tradition, the grand bathing (Snana Yatra) of Lord Jagannath is performed on the full moon day of the month of Jyestha (Jyestha Shukla Purnima). On this day, all four deities (Balabhadra, Subhadra, Jagannath, and Sudarshan) descend from the Ratna Singhasan to the bathing altar and are bathed with 108 golden pots of sanctified water. After this ritual, they take on the form of Ganesha. From that day onward, the deities are considered unwell and do not accept regular food offerings but only medicinal offerings for 15 days. During this period, the temple remains closed. On Ashadha Shukla Pratipada, the deities reappear in their youthful form known as Nava Yauvana Darshan. On the second day (Dwitiya), they are considered healed and proceed to the Gundicha temple on chariots, returning on Dashami. The Ratha Yatra begins with 'Chera Pahara' (sweeping of the chariot platform), symbolizing the purification of body and mind before the Supreme Lord.
rYDSection1: Adi Shankaracharya unified the cultural essence of Bharat by promoting the significance of the four Dhams located in the four directions: Badrinath in the north, Dwarka in the west, Puri in the east, and Rameswaram in the south. It is believed that Lord Vishnu sleeps in Badrinath, bathes in Dwarka, eats in Puri, and meditates in Rameswaram. In alignment with this belief, Lord Jagannath resides in Puri, also known as the Purushottam Kshetra, where He is offered special offerings like rice and lentils (dal-bhat).
rYDSection2: In this sacred Purushottam Kshetra, the temple premises also contain the Rohini Kunda and the Kalpavata (sacred banyan tree). It is believed that after Lord Krishna departed from this world, around 1600 years before the Common Era, worship of Lord Vishnu began near these sacred sites in the form of Neelamadhava by the Sabara tribe. Vishwavasu, a tribal devotee, enshrined the wooden idol of Neelamadhava atop the Nilachal hills. The fame of Neelamadhava spread across India. Around the same time, King Indradyumna ruled in Avanti (present-day Malwa).
rYDSection3: Once, while performing worship, King Indradyumna received divine inspiration to seek a vision of Neelamadhava. Lacking precise information, he sent his Brahmin minister Vidyapati to search for it. Upon reaching Purushottam Kshetra, Vidyapati was not given the truth, as the Sabara tribe kept Neelamadhava's whereabouts a secret. Vidyapati then married Lalita, daughter of the tribal king Vishwavasu, and with her help learned the location. When King Indradyumna finally arrived, the idol had mysteriously vanished.
rYDSection4: King Indradyumna then performed many rituals and sacrifices. Pleased with his devotion, Lord Vishnu appeared in a dream and said He would now manifest not as Neelamadhava but as a divine wooden log (Darubrahma) on the seashore, from which idols must be carved. The next day, a sacred log was found. However, it was so hard that no one could carve it. Then Vishwakarma appeared and agreed to craft the idols in 21 days with the condition that no one would disturb him. A special temple area named 'Gundicha Mandap' was constructed.
rYDSection5: Fourteen days into the carving process, sounds from within ceased. Curious, Queen Gundicha opened the doors. As a result, the idols were left incomplete and Vishwakarma disappeared. A divine voice declared that these incomplete idols would be worshipped. These idols notably lack ears, hands, and feet—yet it is said that Lord Jagannath is omnipresent without feet, hears all without ears, and blesses His devotees without hands. His large, round eyes (chakshu) are especially enchanting to devotees.
historySubheading: From Foundation to Faith – The Temple’s Glorious Journey

aboutHistory.section1: Gupteshwarnagar Vikas Samiti, located in Sector-7, Hiran Magri, Udaipur, is a registered organization. It was established in the year 1997–98, during the early development of the Gupteshwarnagar colony. At that time, the number of residents was limited and unorganized, and people were compelled to live in an environment of insecurity. Hence, organizing the residents and striving for planned development was the need of the hour.
aboutHistory.section2: Social and religious festivals play a vital role in uniting the community. With this belief and public support, temples of Sapteshwar Mahadev, Ambamata, and Hanumanji were built in 1996. Additionally, the Shiv Shakti Mandir Committee was formed to manage the temple premises through community support and to begin organizing events. The Gupteshwarnagar Vikas Samiti was officially registered on 06.01.1998.
aboutHistory.section3: The establishment of Bhagwan Jagannath Dham took place on 29 April 2007. From the beginning, the local residents along with Utkal Samaj (registered as Utkal Samaj Samiti) have provided significant support in its foundation and operations. Recognizing the divine glory of Lord Jagannath, the Shiv Shakti Mandir Committee was renamed to 'Bhagwan Jagannath Dham Shiv Shakti Mandir Committee', which now operates as a branch of the Gupteshwarnagar Vikas Samiti. The temple is located at the center of the Gupteshwarnagar colony and has become a major hub for religious faith and tourism for both locals and visitors. The development of the premises and garden has been greatly supported by the Urban Improvement Trust, Municipal Council, Housing Board, and SBBJ Bank.

descriptionSubheading: An overview of the divine idols enshrined at Bhagwan Jagannath Dham and their sacred worship traditions.
templeDescription: At the Bhagwan Jagannath Dham Temple, the wooden (Mahadaru) idols of Lord Jagannath, Balabhadra, Subhadra, and Sudarshan—sourced from Puri (Odisha)—are enshrined. Alongside them are the incarnations of Varaha, Narasimha, Vamana, the sacred Neel Chakra, the gatekeepers Jaya and Vijaya, the Navagrahas, and Garuda. The temple follows the traditional rituals and worship methods of Jagannath Puri, including the proper installation, consecration, and daily service of the deities.
managementSubheading: The operations of Bhagwan Jagannath Dham are sustained through devoted community support and transparent administration.
templeManagement: All operations of the ‘Bhagwan Jagannath Dham’ Shiv Shakti Temple are managed under the guidance of a committee comprising colony residents and representatives from the Utkal Samaj. These are entirely supported through public donations, worship and offering materials, and other necessary items, with complete transparency in accounting. Receipts are issued for donations received from devotees. Donations are deposited into Account No. 12272151000764, Hiran Magri branch (Udaipur), and all expenses are paid by cheque. If materials are donated, receipts of equivalent value are issued, and details of such donations are recorded. At the end of each financial year, the accounts are audited by a chartered accountant. Major sources of income for the temple include offerings (bhog), donation boxes, festivals, the Ratha Yatra, and others. Major expenses include offerings, honorariums (for priests, gardeners, cleaning staff, etc.), festivals, Ratha Yatra, and others. Key sources of community support include colony residents, Utkal Samaj, and other devotees—some of whom are regular donors.
bhogSubheading: Daily offerings are prepared with purity in the temple kitchen and presented to Lord Jagannath as per sacred tradition.
bhog: Specific offerings (bhog) are made to Lord Jagannath during morning and evening darshans. Cooked or prepared items from outside are not accepted; only raw ingredients are accepted and prepared in the temple's own kitchen. The day begins with a butter and sugar (makhan-mishri) offering and aarti, followed by fruit offerings. In the afternoon, a full meal offering is made, which includes rice, lentils, vegetables, kheer (sweet dish), etc. The Lord rests from 1:00 PM to 4:00 PM, after which darshans are again open until 10:00 PM. At sunset, fruits and aarti are offered, followed by the night offering (bhog), after which the Lord retires. Devotees may offer fruits, coconuts, dry fruits, milk, curd, butter, honey, ghee, etc., as prasadam items. Worship items like camphor, incense sticks, sandalwood paste, flowers, perfumes, dhoop, cotton wicks, and lamps may also be donated.
dressSubheading: Each day, Lord Jagannath is adorned with divine attire of a designated color, lovingly offered by devotees.
dress: Lord Jagannath is adorned daily with garments of specific colors assigned to each day of the week as follows: 1. Sunday – Red, 2. Monday – Purple, 3. Tuesday – Multicolor, 4. Wednesday – Green, 5. Thursday – Yellow, 6. Friday – White, 7. Saturday – Black. Devotees may offer dresses made according to the prescribed color, size, and design, or may contribute financially toward the same. Similarly, they may also donate flags (Dhwaja). Devotees can organize devotional events like Bhakti Sandhya or religious discourses within the temple premises. For such events, a contribution toward cleaning and temple arrangements is to be submitted to the management committee.
teamSubheading: A dedicated group of individuals serving and managing Bhagwan Jagannath Dham with devotion.
visitDescription:
Temple Location: The temple is situated in the southeastern part of Udaipur city, within the Hiran Magri region where new residential colonies like Sector 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 have developed. It lies in the heart of Gupteshwarnagar in the newly developed Sector 7 Housing Board Colony. Approximate distances from key landmarks:
  • Udaipur City Railway Station – 5 km.
  • Roadways Bus Stand – 5 km.
  • Surajpole – 6 km.
  • Chetak Circle – 8 km.
  • Fatehpura – 10 km.
  • Pratapnagar – 7 km.
  • Sevashram Flyover – 4 km.
  • Rana Pratap Nagar Railway Station – 5 km.
  • Paras Tiraha – 4 km.
Note: Auto-rickshaw, and bus services are available from all these locations.

findUsAdrs: Shri Jagannath Dham Sector 7 Udaipur, Rajasthan
findUsDis: Located in the heart of Sector 7, Udaipur — where divinity meets devotion at Jagannath Dham.
donateSubheading: Your contribution helps preserve traditions and sustain daily worship at this sacred temple.
whyDonateSh: Your donation supports temple upkeep, rituals, festivals, and ensures that the light of devotion continues to shine for generations to come.
whyDonate: Your generous donations help sustain Shri Jagannath Dham — supporting daily rituals, temple upkeep, prasadam distribution, and community festivals. Each contribution aids in preserving traditional art, architecture, and spiritual practices. We also invest in cultural and educational programs for future generations. By donating, you become a part of a divine journey that keeps our heritage alive and thriving. Every rupee you offer nurtures devotion and strengthens our collective faith. Let your support become an offering of love and service to Lord Jagannath, inspiring countless others and illuminating lives through spiritual grace.
